Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted rock art on a sandstone rock face, showing two human figures and five unidentified shapes. The clearest human figure stands left of centre facing left. This figure wears a long white apron hanging down before and behind from the waist. To the upper right of this is another figure, facing left and with one leg folded at the knee as if reclining and a raised left arm. Above this figure is a long, thin arc in white domed upward (roof?) with what appear to be four objects (implements?) in brown and white, hanging from it by straps. To the lower right of the rightmost shape, which hangs from a thin brown loop, is an unidentified shape in brown. Magharat el Kantara, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Detail of 2013,2034.89. Magharat el-Kantara is a cave where an overhang forms a low rock shelter. It is located on a promontory separating the Wadi Firaq from the Wadi Wassa in the southern part of the the Gilf Kebir plateau in south-west Egypt. It is the only known rock art site in the south-eastern part of Gilf Kebir. The cave and its cattle paintings were discovered by a member of an expedition led by W.B.K. Shaw in 1935, the account of which was published in Antiquity. It was later investigated by Giancarlo Negro and Yves Gauthier in 1997.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
